Getting a scholarship to study abroad can be the biggest boost for your educational journey and career ahead. It doesn’t just reduce the cost and eases the financial side of your preparation but adds ups to your confidence in your ambitions. Scholarships work two ways – They are either provided by the home country or host country. Home countries have government and private scholarships and exchange programs with scholarships to encourage students to fulfill their study abroad dreams. The host country scholarships work the same way too - There are both government and privately funded scholarships, with varying values and time period and levels of education.  Student-friendly countries like Canada have many options; some are permanently available, while others open for recipients to apply only in particular years. Some of the government-funded scholarships for Canada are: Canadian Commonwealth and Scholarship and fellowship Plan – to cover living and accommodation expenses in Canada for 5-6 months. Ontario Scholarship Program – It is rewarded for a large number of disciplines. The award is valid for two or three sessions amounting to one year or a little over that. National Research Council of Canada – Provides associateship for master’s degree holders and PhD holders in natural science. Quebec Provincial Government Scholarship – For candidates with master’s level and above, valued between $3000 to $25000, for different levels. Partnership Grants by Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada – For PhD candidates to support research initiatives in social sciences and humanities. Banting PostDoctoral Fellowships – For students who wish to pursue PF programs with natural science, social sciences and healthcare. Vanier Graduate Scholarships – To help students pursue a doctoral degree. Besides that, there are many privately funded scholarships inviting students from specific fields as well. Some of them are: Anne Vallee Ecological FundTrudeau Scholarships and FellowshipsEducation Future International ScholarshipAlan Plumtree Graduate Scholarship in Mechanical & Mechatronics Engineering ($20,000)Conrad Family Scholarships for Master’s in Business, Entrepreneurship and Technology (MBET) program ($10,000 to $20,000)Devani Charities Graduate Engineering Entrance Scholarship ($1,500)Roman Baldur Memorial Engineering Award ($2,250)SNC-Lavalin Graduate Scholarship in Engineering ($5,000)Stantec Graduate Scholarship in Civil Engineering ($3,000)Ontario Graduate ScholarshipOntario Trillium ScholarshipUniversity of Manitoba Graduate Fellowship.Specifically for Women in STEM CFUW Memorial FellowshipAmelia Earhart Fellowship (for doctoral programs)Schlumberger Foundation Faculty for the Future FellowshipsThere are many more that you need to stay updated with if you’re planning to apply. Another kind of scholarship in Canada can be obtained on fulfilling some eligibility requirements. In a nutshell, there are options galore for you to avail a scholarship, so work hard for good grades and research well. Heartiest wishes for a bright future!

A recent survey found that students indicated high cost was the greatest deterrent to studying overseas followed by the lack of scholarship opportunities. However, with proper information and planning hopefully no student aspiring to go abroadwill face this predicament and compromise on their academic endeavors. There are a number of scholarships offered by schools, universities and external agencies that can help make studying abroad affordable for Indians. Let’s probe into the various options: 1. University Scholarships.One of the best sources of financial aid can be the college you attend. Universities provide aid through grants and scholarships which do not have to be repaid and can be offered based on need or merit. For example: Tata Scholarships at Cornell University– There is US$25 million endowment from the Tata Education and Development Trust that supports around 20 Indian scholarsat Cornell. To be eligible, it’s necessary to first be accepted into an undergraduate course at Cornell, and then apply for need-based financial aid. The British Council –The British Council recently announced the single largest number of scholarships ever launched in a year in India, by offering around 370 scholarships worth almost 1 million pounds. There are 36 UK institutions participating in this program and scholarships will be offered for 260 undergraduate and postgraduate courses. 2. Current Learning Institutes. The institution you currently attendcould be a resource for financial aid. It’s important to speak to your school and department heads to understand if any scholarships are available and what their admission criteria are. For example: Davis United World Colleges Scholars Program- All graduates of UWC schools who gain admission on their own merits to selected U.S. colleges or universities qualify for need-based scholarship support through the program. The program currently supports over 2,700 scholars at 94 partner colleges and universities throughout the United States. 3. Community Organizations. It is quite common for community groups to encourage and support exceptional members in their academic endeavors. For example: Mustard Seed Foundation (The Harvey Fellows Program) - Provides scholarships to Christian students who are pursuing graduate studies at premier universities in fields considered to be underrepresented by Christians and who possess a unique vision to impact society through their vocations. 4. Private Organizations.There are a number of trusts, foundations and private groups that look to aid exceptional candidates. The criterion varies depending on the ethos of the institution, but you will have to detail why you are the right candidate. For example: RotaryGlobal Grant Scholarship Program - Supports international study at the graduate level and funds graduate-level coursework or research for one to four academic years. It is a partnership between the district / club in the study location and the district / club in the scholar’s home country.The minimum grant amount is US$30,000. InlaksShivdasani Foundation Scholarships – Provides scholarships of up to US$100,000 for exceptional Indian students to study in North America or Europe. The scholarship covers tuition fees, adequate living expenses and one-way travel.Applicants must be under 30 and reside in India at the time of application. NarotamSekhsaria Foundation - Awards interest-free loan scholarships to Indian students with a consistent andstrong academic record. The scholarship amount can be up to Rs. 20 lakhs and is awarded to students who wish to pursue postgraduate studies at prestigious Indian and international universities. 5. Government.The Indian Government, both individually and in collaboration, have launched scholarships to help finance proficient students looking to study outside of India. For example: Government of Telangana– Introduced the “Overseas Study Scheme for Minorities” for the benefit of the students belonging to minority community. Financial assistance will be sanctioned to 500 minority students/graduates per year to pursue Post Graduate/Doctoral studies abroad as per the guidelines. Fulbright-Nehru Fellowships- The Master's Fellowships are designed for outstanding Indians residing in India to pursue a master's degree at selected U.S. colleges and universities. Selected fellows have completed the equivalent of a U.S. bachelor's degree, have at least three years of work experience, and are committed to return and contribute to their communities. There are a number of resources Indian applicants can utilize to fund their study abroad. It’s imperative you do your research, connect with targeted colleges, probe into Government schemes, reach out to external agencies and speak to successful students. Start early and thoroughly explore all the options available before making your final decision. Best of Luck!

Before asking “how”, perhaps you should start by asking “WHY should an average student get a scholarship to study abroad”?There are so many hard up students around the world. Don’t you think the scholarships should be reserved for those who better than average? If a student gets a scholarship when they are average in every way, then there is something wrong with the system. The converse of that, and perhaps a more constructive answer, is: the student should find the thing that that they are better than average at, whether it’s sports, music, art, drama, writing, helping the community, leadership, etc (I’m assuming it’s not anything academic or they wouldn’t be asking this); or find some other way in which they are outside the ordinary (eg the particular challenges they have faced in life). If they’re lucky, it will match something some institution somewhere will want to encourage by offering a scholarship to match.

Scholarships are a gift. They are meant to be used. Some countries more than others offer scholarships for students. It is important to take this into consideration while looking at study abroad options. Countries that offer scholarships for international students are US, Canada, New Zealand and Finland to name the top few. That is not to say that the others don’t offer scholarships but it might be fewer. There are different types of scholarships that one can apply for- government and non-government funded scholarships. Other than these most scholarships are merit based. There are also those that are given for music, sports, leadership and community service. What I have seen is that private universities that are smaller offer a greater amount of scholarships for international students. The advantage of applying for these kind of universities is that the competition for getting these scholarships is not that much and the chances of increasing the amount over the years is more.  As a student, what you need to do is take a look at what is required of you in order to meet the criteria that normally is very clearly stated on university websites. Things like academic rigor, grades in 9, 10 and 11, overall percentage/GPA, etc. are normally aspects that are taken into consideration. It might be a bit of work in doing the research but it definitely is worth your time. So whether you need a scholarship or not, if you think you meet the requirements and have put in the effort to do well through school, then go get that gift! You deserve it.
